service-versions.name: Chef Bootstrap
service-versions.description:
A service that will get a node ready to be consumed by Chef Server. The idea is to do most of what a knife bootstrap command does, minus the assignment of run list items. Currently Linux-only. Once this service completes successfully on the node, you can then use another bash script to run:
chef-client -o 'recipe[your_recipe]'
or you can do:
chef-client -j 'YOUR_JSON_HERE'
on the node.
In this setup, Application Director can act as an orchestrator or composer and manage the provision of clusters, while Chef takes care of the details per-node. This design will still work fully with Chef Server and all the power it provides.
Requirements: - curl installed on the node to be bootstrapped - An accessible HTTP file repository - A validation.pem file hosted in the file repository - A client.rb file that points to the Chef Server hosted on the file repository

props.description: The path that Chef will use for config files on the node.

prop-auto-bind-type.name: None
prop-auto-bind-type.description: Property will not participate in auto-binding.

prop-auto-bind-type.name: None
prop-auto-bind-type.description: Property will not participate in auto-binding.

ns9:component-version-script.script:
# Download and install Chef curl -L https://www.opscode.com/chef/install.sh | bash
# Create Chef's config dir mkdir $chefpath
# Create the validation key wget $file_repo/validation.pem -O $chefpath/validation.pem
# Write the chef-client config file wget $file_repo/client.rb -O $chefpath/client.rb

meta-tag-type.name: OS Family
meta-tag-type.description: Operating System (OS) Family.

supported-os-details.exec-script: trap "APPDEXITSTATUS=\$?;printenv > $2;exit $APPDEXITSTATUS" EXIT # Execute action script source $1 APPDRETURNSTATUS=$? # Unset trap trap - EXIT # Save env variables in output properties file printenv > $2 exit $APPDRETURNSTATUS
